 "In 1983, shortly after Congress approved the bill which would create a national holiday honoring the late civil rights activist Martin Luther King, former New Hampshire Governor Meldrim Thomson sent a letter to his old friend Ronald Reagan, urging the President not to sign the bill for a holiday honoring "the memory of a man of immoral character whose frequent associations with leading agents of communism is well established."
 
 In response to Thomson, the President wrote: "On the national holiday you mentioned, I have the reservations you have, but here the perception of too many people is based on an image, not reality. Indeed, to them the perception is reality." (Emphasis in original.) In other words, Mr. Reagan knew that Martin Luther King was, in reality, unworthy of national adulation.  While you're at it, read the Walsh Report on the Iran-Contra Affair in which they concluded that Reagan had NOT violated any criminal statutes. All that Reagan was "guilty of" was disagreeing with Congress' interpretation of the powers of the Excutive Branch. If you recall, we had a Liberal Democratic Congress trying to restrict a very popular Republican President's power and he wasn't sitting still and letting it happen.
 
 http://www.fas.org/irp/offdocs/walsh/execsum.htm
 "As the White House section of this report describes in detail, the investigation found no credible evidence that President Reagan violated any criminal statute. The OIC could not prove that Reagan authorized or was aware of the diversion or that he had knowledge of the extent of North's control of the contra-resupply network. Nevertheless, he set the stage for the illegal activities of others by encouraging and, in general terms, ordering support of the contras during the October 1984 to October 1986 period when funds for the contras were cut off by the Boland Amendment, and in authorizing the sale of arms to Iran, in contravention of the U.S. embargo on such sales. The President's disregard for civil laws enacted to limit presidential actions abroad -- specifically the Boland Amendment, the Arms Export Control Act and congressional-notification requirements in covert-action laws -- created a climate in which some of the Government officers assigned to implement his policies felt emboldened to circumvent such laws."

 God knows why they don't like Americans. We saved their asses from having to learn German or Italian.

 
 Frogs are green for a reason, envy. :)
Phunting

But as for who Brits dislike, in general, where does Northern Ireland rank? Not above the US? emoticon_confused 
Err Northern Ireland is part of Britain, so we don't generally dislike ourselves! And I'm afraid to say that in order of general dislike it is France and then the US as the top 2 in the world.
 
 
 
And I'm not offended that many Brits don't like Americans. The feeling is mutual here in the US for the most part. Many Americans view Brits as being pompous.
Yeah, we know! In the end we both look at each other through stereotypes. I wouldn't take offense either, it's not an active dislike as such, more of a rivalry. And an excuse to shake our heads and say "bloody yanks" every now and then!
 
 
 
Personally, I get along well with the ones that I've met. I think that Brits, in general, have a great self-deprecating sense of humor and a man that can laugh at himself can't be all bad. ;)
I quite agree. I think that humour is one of the few things we can still do well.
Phunting

I think the French don't really like anybody but themselves. They probably still have animosity toward Britain because Churchill sunk their Naval Fleet after they lost to the Germans.
It goes much further than that. We have been fighting each other almost constantly since the middle ages, through the napoleonic period until empire. In fact the C20th has probably been the first where we were actually on the same side.
Phunting

I believe the Spanish supported the colonists more than the French did. The most significant support from the French was in the form of Lafayette who was actually an unpaid officer in the Continental Army. He was well honored for his services.
 
 Lafayette's support of the colonists was a result of his hatred for the Brits.
I totally disagree with that. France declared war on Britain in support of it's new alliance with the states, meaning the British had to fight a war not only in the colonies, but at home as well totally splitting our forces and putting a severe drain on our economy from fighting a war on two fronts.
 
 King Louis XVI provided supplies, arms and ammunition, uniforms, French troops and naval support. The navy constantly attacked our Armardas, ensuring a hold up of reinforcements arriving. And there is no way Washington would have won Yorktown without the 8,000 French troops that joined him for that battle, doubling his numbers.
georged

I totally disagree with that. France declared war on Britain in support of it's new alliance with the states, meaning the British had to fight a war not only in the colonies, but at home as well totally splitting our forces and putting a severe drain on our economy from fighting a war on two fronts.
 
 King Louis XVI provided supplies, arms and ammunition, uniforms, French troops and naval support. The navy constantly attacked our Armardas, ensuring a hold up of reinforcements arriving. And there is no way Washington would have won Yorktown without the 8,000 French troops that joined him for that battle, doubling his numbers.

 
 Very true. France also forced the then declining Spanish Empire to return portions of the now Louisiana area, including New Orleans, to France which was later included in the Louisiana Purchase. Due to limited investment capital available in the newly formed USA, both France and England then provided most of the capital for the US to expand into the US Southwest, overcoming long established Spanish settlements and land grants in Arizona, Colorado, New Mexico and Texas. Virtually every early trading post in those territories (most of which provided the basis of later cities) was French financed.
jskufan

I think some of you may be over thinking the issue of global American popularity. Regardless of what happened many years ago in wars fought by many nations, I personally feel most of the world has formed their opinions of America and Americans by what they have seen in the last 10 or 20 years, or maybe just our lifestyle in general. I think while almost all other countries welcome American money, most every other country considers Americans to be pushy, selfish, outspoken, wasteful, opinionated, and generally clueless about how the rest of the world lives. I'm an American, and I know that's how I would describe us.

During the 1970s I lived in Hawaii, a US State but culturally and geographically removed to a degree where 'mainlanders' were thought of as foreigners. Demanding, poor manners, aggressive and void of any respect for anyone or anything but themselves. Arrivals were known as full wallets, departing as empty wallets. My travels to other countries quickly made me avoid American tourists at all costs to avoid what would inevitably become embarrassing situations with their demands for instant gratification and constant complaints about everything from food to the 'natives'. A sad but accurate commentary on my countrymen.

 I live within a stone's throw of Canada. I know lots of Canadians living in the US; I know lots of Canadians who have become US citizens and I know many Canadians that work in the US and wish they could live in the US. Maybe if I gave Waxy a list of their names, would that help him out? :)
 The Ambassador Bridge and the Detroit Tunnel are full of Canadians coming over to the US every morning who would love to be able to stay. More higher paying jobs, taxes that are lower here and housing that's reasonably priced are a few reasons.

 I've lived in Canada my whole life, here's my perspective on the USA. Nice place to visit, wouldn't want to live there.
 
 I know ONE guy that would LIKE to live in the US. EVERYONE ELSE would never move there unless they had to for career reasons. My next door neighbor is a doctor, he took a job down there because the offer was too good to refuse. He'll work his 10-20 years and retire in Canada. I know others that have had to go to Houston due to the being the center of the US oil business. Same reason.
 
 I know several people who have gone to school or taken jobs down there out of university, everywhere from Boston, to Wisconsin, to Iowa, ALL could not wait to return to Canada.
 
 I do have one friend that moved to West Virginia. His older brother married into old money while playing hockey at Princeton on a full scholarship. He's on easy street, but still misses Canada.
 
 I've never to been to the Windsor/Detroit area, and I don't doubt your assertion that for some, the grass is greener on the other side of the 49th, but I'm guessing that bridge has some two traffic. 
 
 HOWEVER.
 
 To suggest that most Canadians would give up their life savings to live in the USA, as you've stated JP, is absolutely absurd, and only goes to reinforce the arrogant sterotype that's already being discussed.

 I went back and reread my original post. It was poorly worded. I didn't mean to imply that MOST Canadians would give their life's savings to live here. That portion of my statement was meant for other countries. I put two separate thoughts in one. I should have said "and that includes some Canadians" to be more precise. While I know plenty of Canadians that would love to be permanent US residents, I know at least as many who love Canada. It IS a beautiful country. I'd even consider nominating it for US Statehood if it wasn't for Quebec. :p

georged

It's not a true stereotype I feel, because every single American I has met has not been like that. But then they have all been those who are willing to travel abroad, so maybe they are different to the norm?

 
 From my American point of view I normally enjoy Americans who have or do travel out of choice, not in a tour group, here and outside the US. I find a large majority of people who have not traveled, and I include most overseas military service in that majority, seem to live in a smaller intellectual world. Opinionated doesn't entirely service the definition but I consider them (not all) unable to easily grasp different conditions, thoughts, beliefs and other 'foreign' things outside of their experience. This extends to people from different regions and obviously encompasses most countries, not just the US. When not on his home turf, I've found women much more adaptable than men, many Americans traveling in groups do express an aggressiveness not found in most travelers. A shrink friend said it's insecurity and very common do to the fact most Americans have had 'you're the greatest' pounded into their heads from childhood on and they're in unfamiliar circumstances. Let's face facts; we have a standing president who took us to war on false pretenses and then turned the situation around in American minds to humanitarianism because it was 'right' and the American way. Flag waving removes common sense and reason from many of us.
